turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument now in Number 99-478, Charles C. Apprendi, Jr. v. New Jersey.
Mr. O'Neill.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
This case is about the erosion of the jury by the New Jersey legislature.

The statute at issue in this case violates the Fourteenth and Sixth Amendments by permitting the judge to consider or assess a defendant's mental state by a preponderance of the evidence and sentence that person to a term of up to double the time permitted upon conviction of the predicate crime.
Here, petitioner pled guilty to three crimes, but was sentenced on four.

In Jones v. the United States, this Court constructed a proposed test for constitutionality of the statute as to determine whether the statue creates a separate element of a crime or a sentencing factor.
Any fact, other than prior conviction, which increases the maximum sentence, implicates constitutional protections of beyond a reasonable doubt, notice by--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, what do you do with the capital sentencing schemes in a State like Arizona, for example, where a person can be convicted of first degree murder and then the judge does the sentencing and is allowed to increase the sentence to a death penalty, set it at death, if it was done for, let's say, pecuniary gain, some factor that the judge determines, and this Court has upheld that kind of a scheme.
Now, under your theory that, too, would be invalid if we were to accept what you've just been saying.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --I suggest not, Justice O'Connor, because my understanding of the statutes extant is that they... some of them provide for the death penalty, but that's the maximum, so in States such as those... I'm not intimately familiar with Arizona, but it is the States with which I am familiar, those penalties would be within the maximum and call for proof beyond a reasonable doubt to a jury before the judge sentences.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But in Arizona the jury simply finds a person guilty of first degree murder and leaves the option of life imprisonment, or death, to the judge, so that clearly the judge is imposing a sentence that was perhaps within the range the jury... but it could just as easily have been life.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: I agree with that, Mr. Chief Justice.
However, again, it's within the maximum provided by the statute that the jury knew about, presumably, before they found the defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The jury is told and instructed, don't consider the sentence.
That's not your job.
It's up to the judge.
Don't consider that.
You just determine whether this person convicted... should be convicted of first degree murder.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes, Justice O'Connor.
However, it's my understanding that a statute does provide for not only life, of course, but also, as you point out, death, but within the maximum sentence.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. O'Neill, of course, until our death penalty cases in the 1960's, had not the traditional practice been that a judge in a case where the sentence was up to and including death had the discretion to impose the death penalty or not, or the jury had the discretion to impose it or not?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Justice Scalia--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Wasn't that the traditional rule against which the Sixth Amendment was adopted?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --It is, sir.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And it was our jurisprudence that created the new factor that you could not impose the death penalty unless there were some special facts which had to be found, either by the judge or by the jury, that would justify it, so this is all a creation of this Court.
It has nothing to do with what the Sixth Amendment meant when it was adopted, does it?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: I agree with that, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Maybe I can get at the same question that Justice O'Connor and the Chief Justice had in a slightly different way.
Imagine that I'm in Congress and, as Member of Congress, I tell you the following.
You're my drafter.
I say, here's what I'd like to do.
I'd like to write this criminal statute for bank robbery so that the sentencing works as follows, so that where the gun is loaded, there's a higher sentence.
Where the gun isn't loaded, there's a lower sentence.
That's how I want the sentencing to work.

The crime is bank robbery, but I want these judges to be pretty uniform, and I want them all to give... you know, they have a bigger range where the gun's... you see, where the gun is loaded, and a lower range where it's not loaded.
How do I draft it?
Can I do it?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Justice Breyer, yes, that would constitutional so long as--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: How do I draft it?
What do the words say?
Let's imagine, you know, I want them to have up to 3 years if the gun isn't loaded, but up to 5 years if it is loaded.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --The sentence... the drafting goes something like this, in crude language, that the maximum penalty for commission of such-and-such crime is 5 years.
However, if he then is convicted only of such-and-such, it is a maximum of 3 years.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.

Then if I can do that, then what will happen if you win this case is all that has to happen is that Congress goes back, redrafts all the drug laws, and in the meantime I guess we have new trials of everybody who's been convicted, but they just... it's just a drafting matter, is that right, that all they have to do is write the same thing, but instead of saying the thing goes from 3 to 5 years, 3-year max unloaded and 5-year max loaded, what they do is, they write 5-year max, period, but no more than 3 if it's unloaded.
It's just drafting.
Is that what it is?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, Justice Breyer, I think that Winship spoke in terms of formalism but prescribed against that, so--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Excuse me.
Are you saying that in that case, with that kind of a statute, you would concede that in order to get 5 years, in order to impose 5 years, you would not need a jury finding that the gun was loaded?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --No, I would not concede that, Justice Scalia.
I would concede only--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But that's the premise of the question, I thought.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, it is.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --Well then, I would--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I didn't think you were--

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --I would say only, Justice Scalia and Justice Breyer, that there would have to be the constitutional protections of proof beyond a reasonable doubt as to a jury.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Okay, so what you're saying is, I can't... if I'm Congress, I can't--

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: You can't, under those--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Fine.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --prescribed circumstances.
Fine.
If I can't, my question would be, why not?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Because the constitutional safeguards of beyond a reasonable doubt, and to a jury, are paramount.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I've got that point.

Now my... I'm trying to get you down a little line of questioning here, and then I'd say if that's true, then I guess exactly the same thing is true of the Sentencing Commission does the 3-5 year business, and again I'd say exactly the same is true if a judge does it, which brings us back to Justice O'Connor.

Now, how... I mean, on that line that you've just taken, if I agree with you, I guess I'm holding the Sentencing Commission unconstitutional and, indeed, I guess I'm holding as well unconstitutional the situation where a judge says, defendant, I've looked at the presentence report.
It says your gun was loaded.
You can dispute it, but if the gun is loaded, 5 years.
If it isn't, three.
So you have three situations, judge, Sentencing Commission, Congress.
You've said Congress can do it... cannot do it.
Can the commission?
Can a judge?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, Justice Breyer, in response to that question, I would say this.
If I can use the analogy in the Federal statutes in reference to drug... drugs as to quantity and quality.

Now, I have a fallback position, and that is this, that if the test were something like this, if the maximum sentence is increased and there is required an assessment of the mental state of the defendant, then I think the quality and quantity problems with the drug statute would not be affected.
I respectfully suggest, Justice Breyer, that the Federal sentencing guidelines would not be impacted by the proposed standard, proposed by this Court in Jones.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. O'Neill, I assume you're saying that as long as it's within the upper range that is specified by the legislature, but if you will, instead of engaging in things that you may be less familiar with, let's look at the very statute that you're dealing with, and there are seven factors that would lead to this doubling of the penalty, and the racial/gender animus is just one of them.
In that list of seven, which ones are not encompassed within your constitutional objection?
Which one... even if you won this case, which one, if any, could remain as the New Jersey legislature set it up?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, I would say that the way it's set up, all of them would remain.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, not this one.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Not this one.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Wait, I don't understand.
All of them... they're all valid except this one?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, if we're saying in terms of the question, Justice Ginsburg and Justice Scalia, that if we're talking about race, color, gender, handicap, religion, sexual orientation, or ethnicity, then I think all of them require the same constitutional guidelines.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well then, but what about another one that operates in the same way, is used or was in possession of a stolen motor vehicle?
That would be found by the judge on a preponderance, not beyond a reasonable doubt, and yield for the defendant the same thing.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: If there's a presumption that the underlying crime was found to be violated by the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt to a jury, yes, because it would be within the maximum sentence.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't understand that.
I don't understand your answer.
Would a jury have to find beyond a reasonable doubt that a car was used?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But not under the statute.

The statute sets it up the jury finds assault or whatever is the underlying crime, and then the judge, under subsection (f), the one immediately following subsection (e), your subsection, the judge is instructed that if this crime, this assault was committed and the defendant was at the time in possession of a stolen motor vehicle, then we get kicked up from 5 to 10, to 10 to 20.

So I'm asking you to concentrate on the very next section of the same statute and tell me, you said... you said there was a distinction between the two, and I don't understand why the one would have to go to the jury and the other would not.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, perhaps I didn't state my position clearly enough.

My position is this, Justice Ginsburg, that whenever there is a question of fact which raises the maximum sentence the defendant faces, that requires a constitutional safeguards of beyond a reasonable doubt, and prove to a jury, as well as fair notice.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, suppose that the question of fact is whether the defendant used or was in possession of a stolen motor vehicle?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: I would say that it's a fact that's a jury question.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what about McMillan v. Pennsylvania, where you're talking about crime done with possession of a gun?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, that's a question, Chief Justice, that's easily ascertainable as it is the issue of prior conviction, Almendarez-Torres.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, and wouldn't possession of a motor vehicle, a stolen motor... be equally easily found out?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Most respectfully, Chief Justice, I don't think so.
I think the issue as to whether possession of a stolen motor vehicle occurred or not is subject to some variables to which the possession of a firearm for an unlawful purpose is not.
Also--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Why not?
I mean, that's a fact question, possession of a firearm for an unlawful purpose.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: There you are.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --Justice O'Connor... I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Total fact-based issue.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, it seems to me that in McMillan, it was simple.
It was objective.
There was no question.
There was a shooting of a couple of people involved--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But there's no logical distinction.
I don't see how you can draw that distinction at all.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, McMillan, they didn't raise the maximum sentence, either.
It was within the maximum.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --They did not raise the maximum sentence--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --in McMillan.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes.
Right, but--

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: They required only a sentence within the minimum.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --But that gets you right back to Justice Breyer's drafting question.
If the legislature were to start with the higher sentence and then say, but if no gun is used, 3 years, otherwise, 5, that ought to be all right.
I mean, that's the way you're articulating the test.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes.
I agree with that, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But I think, Mr. O'Neill--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --You said it was not all right.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: But I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Are you going back on that now?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --I say this, Justice Scalia, that all of these requirements must be within the constitutional limits as set forth in cases like Patterson v. New York.
There is a limit to which the legislatures can go.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, what's your answer to Justice Breyer's question?
Just switching it from an affirmative to a negative, does that make the difference?
Not... if you find the fact you get more, but if you don't find the fact you get less.
Does that make the difference?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes.
There's a question of formalism, I think, implied in Justice Breyer's question.
I think that that's been prescribed by this Court previously.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh, well, we're not really arguing about very much, then.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --Of course, how would that example apply to a case like this?
I mean, we're talking about all sorts of different cases, but here the extra fact to be proved was a specific kind of intent.
How can you write a statute that would make that a defense?
I didn't have that intent?
I mean, those examples just don't fit this case.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: We should really try to decide what to do with this case, it seems to me.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: I agree with that, Justice Stevens.
I do.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, I'd like to ask one hypothetical.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Just tell me what the rule was at the common law.
Two people tried with kidnapping.
One of the kidnappers tormented the victims, threatened them, pushed them around.
The other was rather passive.
They're both simply tried with kidnapping.
At sentencing, the judge said, now, you, defendant A, caused much more torment and grief and suffering.
I'm giving you life.
You, defendant B, were rather passive.
I'm giving you 20 years.
Anything wrong with that at common law?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: If life is within the maximum sentence, no, there's nothing wrong with it.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Okay. Now, suppose the legislature specifies that if torment is called... is caused, it would be life, and if not, 20 years, then there's a constitutional requirement?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: I think so.
I think the jury--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But then you can't say, as you did at the outset, that Congress is eroding the jury sentencing.
It seems hard to erode the jury sentencing when all Congress has done is provide some... or the legislature has done is to provide some guidance to its judgment... judges in sentencing.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --Well, it seems to me that the statute at issue does violate the Fourteenth and Sixth Amendments because, by a mere preponderance of the evidence, and I suggest it should be by proof beyond a reasonable doubt, it permits a defendant to assess a mental state of the defendant and submit that person to a sentence of up to double that required in the predicate crime.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if it were proof beyond a reasonable doubt, but to be... the fact to be found by a judge, rather than a jury?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: That might very well be found by your Court to be constitutional.
However, I really believe that that's not enough.
A jury question is involved here.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why would that be okay?
I don't understand that.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, because--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean--

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --it satisfies the constitutional test of--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Because we're illogical or something?
I mean--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, aren't you resting on the distinction that is inherent in McMillan?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --I am.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes, because--

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes, Justice Souter.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --you... depending on whether you are raising the jury issue or the due process notice/reasonable doubt issue, you may get different results in different cases, and McMillan is an example, I suppose.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes.
As long as it's within the maximum, not outside the maximum.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is... when you said mental state, isn't this motive a mental state that is primarily... motive is a mental state that's primarily used for sentencing.
I couldn't think of a single statute where motive is actually an element of the crime.
Intent is a motive of the crime.

Sometimes intent does give you a motive, but motive itself, he did it out of hatred, he did it out of revenge, he did it out of race hatred, he did it because the person killed his father, all those are backward-looking, or emotional motives.
I've never... can't think of a single statute where that's an element of a crime.
I mean, of course, there are other States that have made it in this instance, but isn't it a traditionally sentencing factor?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: It is, Justice Breyer.

However, there are cases... there have been cases arising out of this Court, like Haupt v. United States, where motive was found to be a necessary ingredient of a crime charged, but traditionally I agree with Your... Justice Breyer that traditionally motive is a sentencing factor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's a discretionary sentencing factor, though, traditionally, isn't it?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's up to the judge.

If he wants to take motive into account, he may, and if he doesn't want to, he need not, and the defendant who has the motive is subject to up to 50 years, and the defendant who does not have the motive is subject up to 50 years.
Isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: It certainly is, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So why... what... I don't... what difference does it make whether it's a traditional sentencing factor?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, I don't think it makes any difference, because I think while a lot cases have distinguished between motive as opposed to purpose, intent, mens rea, mental state--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But may I stop you there, Mr. O'Neill, because you seem to be conceding that this is a sentencing factor, and then not traditional, but I'm looking at the words of the statute.
It doesn't say motive.

It says, with a purpose to intimidate, and it seems to me there are many criminal statutes, burglary statutes, for example, that use those words, with a purpose to, and the jury has to find that purpose.

So why are you conceding that this is ordinarily for the judge and with a purpose... in answer to Justice Breyer, who said there are no statutes that make this... that this is extraordinary, but with a purpose to, it seems to me is in a number of statutes.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, I'm not, most respectfully, conceding that.
All I'm saying is this, that while the statute in New Jersey uses the term, purpose, it could have used motive.
It did not.
It used the term, purpose.

To me, they are... they should be considered, whether it's motive, purpose, in this particular statute the same, although traditionally I agree that we're talking about modus, motive, we're talking about mens rea, we're talking about intent, mental state... they're all the same.
Some people have said in their opinion, some jurists, that motive is different, but here I don't think it makes a difference.

What's important here is that there is a sentence to a much... or a... an exposure to a much higher or stiffer sentence if there is proof that a person committed a crime with a purpose to intimidate because of race.
That requires--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --How about for the purpose of pecuniary gain?
That's another one on this laundry list that kicks you up into the next sentencing--

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --Yes, against person or property I think the statute says, Justice Ginsburg.
--Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But isn't that... wouldn't at least that one have to be decided the same way as this one?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Oh, I think so, yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I thought you told me that all the other ones would stand except this one, on your argument.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, I did say that, but I guess I was confining my consideration to the facts and the law in this case, which have to do with purpose to intimidate an individual because of race.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So I take it now, on rethinking, you have concluded that some on this list would have to go the same way, and that maybe for pecuniary gain is one of them.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: I think so.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: In terms of the basic fairness of it... and I think Justice Ginsburg had a good point, actually.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: This is written in terms of purpose, so whether it's intent, or purpose, or motive, treat them the same.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But you've represented clients, I take it, where sometimes perhaps in your career you had a tough choice.
You wanted to say, well, the client was in Chicago, but just in case he wasn't, I want to tell you it was only 300 grams of drugs and not 400.

Now, that... the client sometimes is in an awkward situation with that kind of... and why is it fundamentally unfair for Congress, or a legislature, to say, look, race hatred is very emotional... very emotional... and you inject that into the trial, and suddenly you'll discover people being very emotional about the conclusion.
We think it's fairer for defendants, as well as for victims, to take that issue out and make it a sentencing factor for the judge.
Is that fundamentally unfair to make that decision?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes, Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Because?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And if it is fundamentally unfair, I guess it's just as fundamentally unfair if the Sentencing Commission makes it.
In fact, it's worse, because it's not just a maximum, it's a minimum, or the sentence you're really going to get, and I guess it's even worse when a judge does it, on his own.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, so long as the statute does not provide for an increase in the maximum sentence, then I think it's okay to have a mandatory minimum sentence, as in McMillan.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You should actually be grateful for this--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --You see, that's what's actually bothering me, because a mandatory minimum is much worse for defendants than an increase in the maximum.
It's much worse, and a sentencing guideline which says, do it in the ordinary case, is much tougher on defendants than just increasing the statutory maximum.
We both know that.

And therefore, why, in terms of fairness, do you say the Constitution prevents the increase of the statutory max, not the minimum mandatory, which is much worse, and not the sentencing guideline, and not the judge doing it on his own?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Justice Breyer, I say this, that I don't concede that it's necessarily worse to have a mandatory minimum.

I think it's... it can be, it cannot be, but I think really it's much worse to be exposed to a term of imprisonment significantly greater than that which you faced at the time you pleaded to the indictment.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. O'Neill, I thought we were discussing the meaning of the Sixth Amendment, not the philosophical question of which is worse than something else, and I thought you were resting primarily upon the unbroken tradition of the Sixth Amendment that if you are liable for an increased penalty, the fact that makes you liable for that increased penalty has to be found by the jury.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: That's precisely my position.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So--

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: That's my bedrock position, Justice--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --whatever the philosophical pros and cons of that may be, your argument is, that's what the Sixth Amendment meant.
That's what its tradition has been throughout its history.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --Well put.
That's exactly my position, Justice Scalia.
[Laughter]
Thank you.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But you agreed--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Shall we charge Justice Scalia's question to your time?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But you agreed with me that under the common law and the kidnapping hypothetical the judge would have the discretion to sentence the defendant who caused torment to the victims much more severely than the other defendant.
You agreed with that.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: So long as it's within the maximum, not extended beyond the maximum, Justice--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So all you're doing--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --You wouldn't agree if there was--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --All you're doing is saying that the legislature cannot prescribe what judges will do.
That's what you're saying.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --Well, within constitutional limits they can.
That's the State's rights, to define crimes and punishments, but only within constitutional limits.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You can argue all by yourself, without any questions.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, it would seem to me, Mr. Chief Justice, that the words of the statute, with purpose to intimidate, are the very essence of the statute in question here, and purpose intent has to be an ingredient of the crime, and when purpose or intent is an ingredient of a crime, its existence is a question of fact.
That is a jury question.

A purpose, a question of purpose or intent can never be ruled as a question of law, but it always must be submitted to the jury, and the jury... the New Jersey statute here is unconstitutional because it takes from the defendant the constitutional rights to proof beyond a reasonable doubt to a jury after fair notice, and it takes from the jury the very essence of its existence, which is that as a fact-finder and, finally, it seems to me that if a person is stigmatized by conviction as a racist, that should be rendered by the broadest cross-section of the community, which is the jury.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I take it, Mr. O'Neill, that you would, on your reasoning, also find New Jersey's harassment statute unconstitutional because it does the same thing.
It says a person who commits this crime, if he acted with a purpose to intimidate because of race, color, religion, et cetera.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, Justice Ginsburg, it's interesting to me to note that for that lesser crime in New Jersey, either sexual harassment involving race or racial assault, that the stringent requirements are much more severe, because it... the statute requires proof beyond a reasonable doubt to a jury on those minor crimes, whereas this major crime, this very serious crime, it doesn't.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I don't see that.
The section that I'm looking at is set up... uses the same words as the section that we're dealing with here.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Where is this?
Is this in the papers somewhere?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: This is the racial harassment statute for which this person was indicted, but he didn't plead to that, is that correct?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes, Justice Ginsburg.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't know what we're talking about here.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: There's another statute in New Jersey... I'll give this to Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Do you want me to address that, Justice Scalia?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I haven't read it before.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: It... I assume it would go the same way because the words are the same, but--

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But who has to make the finding of harassment under that other statute, the jury?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: The jury... the jury, Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well then, that's totally consistent with your position.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: It certainly is, Justice Stevens.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: That's not what the statute says.

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: Well, my point here, to respond to Justice Scalia's point last, is that when you have a charge, indictable charge in New Jersey for racial assault or racial harassment, the proofs required are beyond a reasonable doubt to a jury, unlike in the case at bar in Apprendi, where you'd have a situation where you only have to prove by a preponderance to a sentencing judge that there's a violation of purpose with intent to intimidate because of race.
That's the difference.
They have a higher standard of proof for a lesser crime in New Jersey than they have for the much stiffer crime, lesser proof, preponderance.
That's unconstitutional, I respectfully suggest.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do you wish to reserve the balance--

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: I would--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --of your time?

turn.speaker: joseph_d_oneill
turn.label: Mr. Joseph D. O'Neill
turn.text: --Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, Mr. O'Neill.
Mr.... Ms. Gochman, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

The New Jersey legislature has made clear, and the New Jersey supreme court has confirmed, that the extended term provision of the hate crime statute which addresses motive is a sentencing factor, and not an element of the predicate offense.

Motive, as this Court has recognized over 100 years ago, may be probative of guilt, but it is not essential to a conviction unless the legislature chooses to include it as an element of a particular offense.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So I suppose that means that the New Jersey legislature could provide for first degree murder is murder with malice aforethought, and could provide the death penalty for that crime, and could leave it up to a judge to decide whether there was malice aforethought, and to decide that just by a preponderance of the evidence?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Respectfully, malice aforethought is not the same as motive.

Malice aforethought is that yes, you intended to commit this crime, but even with malice aforethought, the prosecution does not need to prove the defendant's motive, why did he want to commit the crime.
He may have wanted to kill somebody because he owed him money, because he made some sort of unwarranted advances.
But malice aforethought has always been deemed intention, and part of mens rea, and it's different from motive.
Motive goes to the underlying reason.
In this case, for example, the defense, by its plea of guilty, satisfied the elements of New Jersey's possession of a weapon for an unlawful purpose.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Traditionally, as I understand the common law, there was no inquiry into motive.
It was just intent.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The motive didn't make any difference.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: That's correct, so malice--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What about an espionage prosecution?
Someone has stolen papers, highly secret papers from the Defense Department.
It is treason punishable by death if the reason they were taken was to give them over to a foreign power--

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --If Congress--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --that is hostile to the United States.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --If Congress chose to make that motive an element of that particular crime, then yes, that would have to go to the jury.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, if... Congress... no, I... Congress chooses not to make it an element.
Congress just says, anyone who takes papers from the Defense Department that are classified secret is guilty of an offense, 10 years in prison.

However, if the purpose of taking them is to give them over to a foreign power hostile to the United States, the death penalty, and the latter question will be decided by a judge on the basis of whether it's more likely than not.
You know, it's a close question, but on balance I think it's more likely than not that he should get the death penalty.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Under this Court's capital--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That would be okay?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Under this Court's capital jurisprudence, that would be permissible--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --so long as the jury finds beyond a reasonable doubt the elements of the predicate offense.
It then goes to the judge to determine the aggravating factors, including--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --That doesn't shock you, that outcome at all?
I mean, that seems to you in accord with our traditions of jury trial and proof beyond a reasonable doubt?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --That's in accord with this Court's jurisprudence on death penalty cases.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Death penalty cases are cases apart.
I mean, death penalty cases are not in accord with our jurisprudence on anything else, and to... you know, to decide this case on the basis of death penalty cases would be extraordinary.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Well, respectfully, Your Honor, if a judge can increase a defendant's sentence from life imprisonment to death based on aggravating factors, and that's constitutional under the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments, then certainly it would be constitutional to increase the petitioner's sentence by a mere 2 years on a noncapital offense.
It's the same... we're dealing with the same constitutional amendments and the same clauses.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, but the difference is, as Justice Scalia, I guess, has already pointed out, that in the one case the legislature has authorized the death penalty for the facts found by the jury, not in his case.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Well, it would be the same thing.
The legislature has authorized a higher sentence when the judge makes a--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But only... but in his example, if the additional fact is found by a preponderance of the evidence by a judge, and that can make the difference, in your view, between a 10-year sentence and a life sentence.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --It may be disproportionate under another constitutional framework, but it's not unconstitutional within this particular framework of the Sixth Amendment that we're dealing with here.
Perhaps it's disproportionate, but this Court said--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What if a legislature had a statute that authorized a crime called wrongdoing, just prove anything wrong, and then it had a... and the jury has to find the wrong, but then the judge is directed to impose a whole range of sentences, depending on what the wrong is, and he has to do it just by a preponderance of the evidence.
I suppose that would be perfectly okay.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --No.
That would probably go way too far.
That would be too extreme.
It's very vague.
It's very overbroad.
It wouldn't give notice to criminal defendants of exactly what their conduct was, what the requisite mens rea was.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, they could perhaps have a checklist of 95 different things that would qualify as wrongdoing.
Any one of those is found, then you turn over the matter to the judge, and from there on it's up to the judge on the basis of the preponderance of the evidence, and no jury required.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Well, we're not suggesting at all that we can take away from the prosecutor's burden to prove mens rea beyond a reasonable doubt, or any of the traditional elements of traditional offenses.
That's not at all what we're arguing here, so that that hypothetical would, of course--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, what is the constitutional line, in your view, about what can be an element, and what can be a sentencing factor?
What's the line?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Well, in common law, elements of the offense had to be the mens rea, the actus reis, and the causation, and at least in New Jersey grading provisions are by legislative grace, not by constitutional prerogative, so that you look to the common law, see what the bedrock elements of those particular crimes were, and when the prosecution starts to shift the burden of proof to the defendant, or when the legislature crafts a statute that includes presumptions of guilt, then, of course, we're going too far, but that's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But there were all sorts of mens rea.
You speak of mens rea as though it's one single, narrow thing.

There were different mens rea for different crimes, and all that is going on here is that the New Jersey legislature has defined a special mens rea for this crime that gets a higher penalty, namely, among the other mental dispositions, there has to be the mental disposition of committing this crime because of hostility on the basis of race, or whatever the other factors are.
That's mens rea.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --The crime to which defendant pleaded guilty is possession of a weapon for an unlawful purpose, and it already has a mens rea element and that is, petitioner's purpose, or conscious objective, was to use the firearm against the person or property of another, and he satisfied that element of the offense when he pleaded guilty and said that he fired his rifle into the house of the Fowlkes family in order to scare them.
That was all that the prosecution had to prove in order to find this defendant guilty of--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And then New Jersey has added an additional mens rea element and it says, if there's this additional one, this additional mental disposition, we're going to give you a higher penalty, but this second one, we're not going to let it go to the jury.
We're going to let the judge find it by a preponderance.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Well, our position--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's still mens rea.
I don't see how you can, you know, single out some things that you can play with this way and other ones that you can't on the basis of some distinction between mens rea and other things.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Two answers to that, Your Honor.
First of all, our position is, is that it's not mens rea.
Motive is a sentencing factor that does not have to be proved to the jury beyond a reasonable doubt in any prosecution unless the legislature chooses to make it an element of the offense.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And if it makes it an element of defense, its mens rea.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: No, it's not mens rea.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Oh, it's still a--

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: It's an additional aggravating factor that, by legislative grace, the legislature has required the prosecution to prove.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Would you call it actus reus?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: It's not actus reus, it's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's neither actus reus, nor mens rea, it's some--

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Well, even to the extent, if this Court wants--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --some third thing that we never heard of before.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --If this Court wants... well, Your Honor, in Pointer v. United States back in 1894, I believe it was, this Court held that motive is never an essential element of the crime, and that was murder in that particular case.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, it has, but hasn't it also been the case traditionally that motive... and let's just stick to motive for a minute... has never had the significance that it has under the New Jersey statute.

The motive, so far as I know, has never traditionally been the difference between 10 and 20 years and if, therefore, the motive is not part of the definition of the crime, and it does not go to the permissible sentence, the law in effect sort of shrugged and said, so what, it's not that important to anything that is essential in the constitutional structure.
But New Jersey has chosen to give it a very different role, and therefore I don't see why the traditional shrug about motive has any relevance today.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: There are several types of motive that are used in capital juris... in capital sentencing schemes, including--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, may I interrupt you just... your answer just for a second.
Is... am I correct that this tradition of shrugging at the motive grows out of a tradition in which the motive does not determine the maximum sentence?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is that historically true?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I've been assuming it is.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --But under death penalty schemes it can be used to increase the sentence to death.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You said traditionally.
Death penalty schemes are a creation of the last 20 years.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't consider that much of a tradition.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --If the tradition is that sentencing judges had wide discretion in a wide range of statutory... or not statutory, but maximum sentences, then certainly motive--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Within maximum sentences set by the legislature, or, in an earlier day, under common law crimes.

We don't have common law crimes any more, so that to the extent that we have a traditional analogy, I have been assuming that that analogy involved cases in which the motive did not affect the maximum penalty, and I'm right about that, am I not?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --I believe that you are.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: But at that point also judges had wide ranges and could impose a sentence up to life imprisonment based on a person's bad motive, just as the same that a judge could give a lesser sentence--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, they had whatever range the legislature specified, but the range did not increase depending on whether there was a finding of motive or not a finding of motive.
The judge simply exercised discretion within the range.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Right, and now what the legislature is doing is simply giving greater guidance to sentencing courts in how to--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, it's doing a lot more than giving guidance.
It's increasing the penalty.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --When you look at the New Jersey sentencing code... elements of the offenses and the substantive crimes are found in the first part of the New Jersey Criminal Code.

Sentencing provisions are in the latter part, so that when a defendant is charged in an indictment and he's given a... he's told what particular offense he has... he's charged with, he then has to go to the sentencing section to find out what types of sentences he may be eligible for.
He may be eligible for mandatory minimum sentences, mandatory increasements, or extended terms, so it's... you have to look--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What is... I'm not getting the drift of the argument.
What difference does this make?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --That when defendant was charged with possession of a weapon for an unlawful purpose, it was not necessarily under the New Jersey code that all he was going to get at the end of this prosecution was a maximum of 10 years.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: He knows that.
He says, I might get 20 years, depending on a certain finding, and that's why I have a right to a jury trial.
That's his point.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: But there are other facts as well that a sentencing court can take into consideration.
For example--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: He recognizes that, too, but he says, those facts do not increase the range of permissible sentence from 10 to 20 years, and therefore I accept the fact that under the traditional scheme, which we assume to be constitutional, the judge may find those facts within the range if they are not defined as elements.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --In this Court's opinion in Almendarez-Torres v. United States, this Court held that an increase in sentence based on a traditional sentencing factor, there it was recidivism, was constitutionally permissible.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: It sure did, and the Court also emphasized about a half-a-dozen times that recidivism was in a unique place in sentencing jurisprudence.
Almendarez-Torres did not purport to create a rule for nonrecidivism factors.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Well, of course, it did not have to.
It was only addressing that particular statute.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, it didn't have to, but it didn't have to emphasize the uniqueness of recidivism, either.
Whether the distinction is a good one or not, it seems to me the point is you can't rely upon Almendarez-Torres for your position because the Court wrote very narrowly in Almendarez-Torres.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Ms. Gochman, now, in my day as a sentencing judge it was not uncommon to have statutes making a crime, let's say of robbery, punishable for anything from 1 year to life.
Let the judge decide.

And within that range, it was not uncommon for judges to consider such things as the motive of the crime, or the lack of remorse, if that was the case, by the defendant, or, if you had a defendant that just appeared to be absolutely without remorse, and intending to create as much trouble as he could for black citizens, the judge could take that into consideration and impose the life sentence rather than the 1 year.
Now, that was traditional, wasn't it--

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --for a long time around the country.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And what we see today is a series of sentencing schemes that have imposed greater restrictions on the sentencing judge, given them narrower options, is that correct?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And within that, the legislative branch has tried to say, well, if there really is lack of remorse or a bad purpose here, you can increase the sentence.
Is that what's happening?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: That's correct and, indeed, in this particular instance the defendant has probably been given more due process than was given under a--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Let me just interrupt you right there.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --more discretionary scheme.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If we go back to the general discretion that Justice O'Connor described, and you apply that in this case, it would be permissible for this additional sentence to be imposed on the basis of a report made by the parole officer in the pre... in the post... in the presentence report, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Not under the New Jersey statute, which requires--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, but I mean, constitutionally it would be permissible.
You'd have everything the same, except you don't need preponderance of the evidence.
All you need, the parole officer's recommendation, and the judge could rely on that and increase the sentence by 10 years, if you want to go back to the old way of sentencing.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --So long as the defendant had the opportunity to rebut that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, he didn't even need the opportunity to rebut it in the traditional, old days.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Well, we've come very far from there, and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, let me ask this about the traditional old days.
Suppose... did the defendant in the traditional old days have an entitlement not to get more than 1 year if he was shown to be really remorseful?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --I'm not sure, Your Honor.
I don't know if that sentencing scheme was fit within a particular crime, or--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Gee, you were very familiar with the traditional scheme when Justice O'Connor described it, and--

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Well, I'm not sure about--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --all of a sudden it's not clear.
It's a traditional statute for this crime, 1 year to life.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Okay.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Now, if the defendant showed enormous remorse, would he be entitled... entitled... to get only 1 year, or only 20, or only 30?
He had no entitlement whatever, did he?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If he did the crime, he knew he got life, and if he got any less than life it was a matter of grace and good luck, and if he got a hanging judge, too bad.
You did the crime.
That's the risk you took.
Wasn't that the system?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: That--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Now, there are no risks here.
Here there is an entitlement to get a lesser sentence.
Isn't there an absolute entitlement unless you are found to have this state of mind?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Not if it's a sentencing factor, because it's not a state of mind.
State of mind goes to the underlying--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You're saying he's not entitled even if--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Let her answer.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: She's answering the wrong question, Chief Justice.
Assuming that the judge does not find by a preponderance of the evidence that this mental state existed, is he not entitled to get the lower sentence?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: All right, and there was--

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: But he is... it's not an entitlement.
It is by statutory prerogative that he must get that letter sentence.
The judge must make a finding by a preponderance of the evidence.
So yes--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --But if--

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --the same words.
Entitlement or--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Okay.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Or by statute.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And there was no such entitlement under the traditional 1 year to life system.
There was nothing you were entitled to.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: Well then, we've given defendant more due process than an older system.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, that's true, but when you give entitlements, what go along with the entitlements are certain requirements, including the requirement of the Sixth Amendment.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: May I ask you, Ms. Gochman, a defendant says, I don't understand this because my buddy committed a crime.

It was called burglary, and that statute said, with a purpose to, and he went to a jury, and they had to find beyond a reasonable doubt, and I'm being charged with a statute that also says, with a purpose to, and the jury falls away, beyond a reasonable doubt falls away.

Explain to me why the legislature, using the very same words, with a purpose to, in the one case can say, oh, this is just for the judge and the other must, as a matter of constitutional right, give it to the jury.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: The New Jersey supreme court has interpreted the phrase, with a purpose to, in its proper context and that is motive, and this Court is, of course, bound by that court's--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: It's not motive when it appears in the burglary statute?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --It's not the ultimate motive, not at all, in the burglary statute, if a defendant has burglarized a house with a purpose to commit a felony within, but again the prosecution doesn't have to prove why that person wanted to commit the felony.
Did he want to commit a robbery because he had a claim of right to that money?
Did he want to commit a robbery because he wants to feed his drug habit?
Did he want to commit a robbery because he wanted to feed his hungry family?
That is motive, and that the prosecution does not have to prove.
Yes, we have to show that he entered that residence or business with the purpose to commit another offense, but we don't have to prove why he wanted to do so.

That part is motive, and that's distinct from the intent, which is the purpose to in the burglary statute, and when read in its proper context, as the New Jersey supreme court has interpreted it, with a purpose to equals by its motivation, and that is a sentencing factor, because we did not have to prove that to prove--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Gochman.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_gochman
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Gochman
turn.text: --Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. DuMont, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
In this case, what New Jersey did was to convict petitioner of a very traditional, conventional crime, possession of a weapon for an unlawful purpose.
It's a crime with a long common law tradition.
It seeks to punish him more severely than it otherwise would for that crime for an equally conventional reason, that he acted with a particularly bad purpose.

Now, that sentencing policy decision does not, in our view, become unconstitutional simply because the State specified the bad motive factor in a statute and required the judge to find it by a preponderance of the evidence before he was permitted to go over a certain level in the sentence.
Now, we all agree, I think, that a legislature normally may define the elements of a crime and fix the minimum and maximum punishments for that crime.

What the legislature does in these cases is to make a subsidiary decision that a particular factor is not sufficiently central to guilt or innocence, or perhaps it would be so cumbersome or unfair to present at trial that it should not be sent to the jury as an element of the offense, but that it is important enough, in the legislature's view, to the proper punishment for the offense that the judge should be constrained in his sentencing decisions in that finding this factor by a preponderance... not by reasonable doubt, but by a preponderance... should be necessary before the judge may go over a certain level in sentencing.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: Mr. DuMont, that's just the problem.
You agree that if it's an element of the offense it goes to the jury.

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: You agree that if it's an enhancement it can go to the judge.

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: As a sentencing factor.

The difficulty I have is that nowhere have we defined what the distinction is between an element of the offense and an enhancement factor, and if you could do that in your few minutes it would be very helpful.

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: Well, it is a tall order.
What the Court has said... I think I can give you parameters.
The Court has said, on the one hand, that it is almost always the legislature's prerogative to define the elements of the offense.
The Court has also said, made very clear in this series of cases, that there are limits past which the legislature may not go consistent with due process and the jury right.

An example we would be willing to give, if a legislature tried to define double parking as a petty offense subject to a fine, but then said, if the judge finds that you were double-parked because you were going to escape from a bank robbery, then it's life imprisonment, we think that would be so contrary to our traditions and so obviously abusive, that it would be on the other side of the line.
But that line has to be drawn very far out in order to give proper due to the legislature's prerogative.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What's the criterion for the drawing of the line?
Now, do you agree with the State of New Jersey?
As I understand the State's position, it's that anything can be made a sentencing factor which was not a traditional element, that if it's a traditional element, it has to remain an element.
If it's a traditional sentencing factor, it can be made a sentencing factor.
Is... do you agree with that line?
That's how I understand the State's argument.

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: We think tradition and common practice are helpful guides in looking at a particular statute, but no, they don't define a particular line.
I guess I would have two answers to the question of what is the line.

At the furthest doctrinal level, I think that the best answer I can give you is that if the Court becomes convinced beyond, if I may use the phrase, a constitutional doubt, that a legislature is punishing a defendant for something other than the crime described by the elements of the crime of which he was convicted, then there is reason for grave concern, and possibly that statute is unconstitutional.

But it must be remembered that a legislature has wide right to define crimes and to punish them very severely, so the question to be asked, to take Justice Scalia's hypothetical, for instance, from his dissent in Monge, of the statute that says, any intentional causing of harm is a crime, and everything else is a sentencing factor, you have to start with the supposition that the legislature could not enact that offense just as a crime and then say, it is a crime, and the sentence is up to life imprisonment or death in appropriate cases, and the judge decides.
Now, if that is constitutionally problematic, which we think it probably would be, it's probably the same constitutional problem that we can see here.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Do you think it's a problem for a legislature to say robbery is punishable by anything from a year to life?

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: No.
No, not at all.
My point is only that at some extreme there may be a due process or a jury trial when the... on even just imposing a crime and imposing a punishment of up to life imprisonment or death.
Now--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: How about a narrower example?
Instead of saying, all wrongdoing, let's say all theft.
All theft is punishable from zero to life.

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: --On its face, the statute is constitutional.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Then you basically, in the real world, are saying the legislature is going to determine when there is a jury right and when there isn't.
I mean, I don't see how you can escape that conclusion.

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: I think that's correct, and I think that's the way it's always been except for common law crimes, and common law crimes were crimes that were defined by courts, and they were always understood to be at the pleasure of the legislature if the legislature chose to make a different disposition.
Now--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why do you say that's the way it's always been?
I don't understand what you mean by that.
I don't--

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: --Well, take the Federal system.
Congress is the only body that can define a crime, so if you don't have a congressional enactment, you don't have a statute, you don't know what the elements are and, in fact, there are no elements.
There is no crime.
So, of course, whether you get a jury trial right always depends on what the legislature has defined to be a crime.
Now, if I can just address for a moment the Jones rule, because I think... we have two points to make about the proposed Jones rule.

One is that it would cut out a lot of legislative conduct that to us is perfectly legitimate and even laudable, and if you take the traditional robbery, or, say, a kidnapping statute that says... the Federal one says zero to death, actually, and that's what the statute says now.

Suppose Congress says, well, we'd like to bring a little more order to the sentencing process, so we think it's going to be presumptively 25 years, but if a child is involved, or there was bodily injury, then it's going to be 25 to 40, and if someone was killed, if the victim was killed, then it ought to be from 40 to life.

Now, you can look at that statute and say, this is terrible for defendants because now they've been deprived of their jury right, or you can look at it and say, that's terrific for defendants, because two-thirds of the defendants now have a 25-year cap on their sentence, so we don't see the fundamental fairness argument here.
The second point to be made about the Jones rule--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Excuse me.
In those cases I assume the judge must impose 20 years if a certain factor is found, and must impose 40 years if a certain factor is found.
Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: --It can be written either way.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It can be written--

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: It can be written either as a mandatory minimum of 20 and then up to 40, or it can be written as, that the range increases to 40 years if somebody was injured, because--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --But in any event, even on that answer, he may not impose the higher sentence unless the fact is found.

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: --That's correct, but what the--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So there is a limitation on the judge which creates in Justice Scalia's question to your friend a moment ago an entitlement which didn't exist before.

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: --But the entitlement is only to have the judge make that determination by a preponderance of the evidence.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, that's a way of defining the problem out of existence.
The entitlement is an entitlement not to get a sentence beyond a certain point unless a fact is found.
What consequence follows for a judge/jury is another question, but there's an entitlement not to have a sentence beyond a certain point.

turn.speaker: edward_c_dumont
turn.label: Mr. Edward C. DuMont
turn.text: That is true, but the question you have to face is why you should erect a flat constitutional bar to the legislature making that choice, and that is informed by this analysis, I believe.

If the legislature knows it has only two choices, zero to life, or make these into elements of the offense and require proof beyond a reasonable doubt, it may decide they're not important enough for that, and that is not very protective of defendants.
